I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Papua New Guinea (PNG) recognizes that the private sector plays a 
central role in contributing to economic growth and acknowledges the need for reform of the 
business environment, as evidenced by public discussions, statements of policy and intent, and 
strategy documents. The Government’s Medium-Term Development Strategy (MTDS)1 includes 
policies to encourage greater private sector participation in the economy. The Government has 
highlighted three main elements as critical to achieving a strong economy:2 (i) creating a stable 
investment climate; (ii) providing an efficient, effective, and affordable public sector; and (iii) 
creating a competitive and dynamic private sector. 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) completed a private sector assessment (PSA)3 in 
2003 which is currently being updated.4 The PSA analyzes the country’s business environment 
and suggests measures to help the Government identify and remove the obstacles to growth of 
the  private  sector.  In  PNG,  momentum  has  been  established  to  improve  the  enabling 
environment  for  private  sector  development  and  create  opportunities  for  reform.  This  is 
underscored by on-going government initiatives such as the establishment of the National 
Working  Group  on  Impediments  to  Business  and  Investment  (NWGIBI),  as  well  as  the 
encouragement of feedback from stakeholders. Private sector representatives have expressed 
support for resolving the issues raised in the PSA and provided input to the design of this 
technical assistance (TA), which ADB has agreed to support. The Government has asked ADB 
to provide technical TA support for developing and initiating private sector-related economic 
reforms. 
 
3.  The TA design and monitoring framework were discussed with Government and private 
sector stakeholders in the course of 2005 in conjunction with the development of the country 
strategy and program update (CSPU) and a visit to PNG in August 2005.5 Stakeholders have 
concurred with the proposed impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, 
financing arrangements, and consultant terms of reference. The TA framework is in Appendix 
1.6 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
4.  Over the past 5 years, economic growth has barely kept pace with population growth. 
The gross domestic product (GDP) increased by 2.6% in 2004 and is forecast to grow by 3.4% 
in 2006. The knock-on effects of this growth to the PNG economy is expected to be significant. 
However, the health of the economy depends largely on buoyant commodity prices, and the 
current  enabling  environment  is  not  strong  enough  to  support  business  development  and 
broader economic growth benefiting the population at large. The CSPU acknowledges that the 
challenge of promoting an enabling environment for the private sector requires bringing about 
critical changes to reduce obstacles to private sector activities and promote their expansion.

The  CSPU  also  states  that  private  sector  organizations  should  be  supported  to  increase 
demand for reform and to strengthen the quality of dialogue with the Government. 
 
5.  PNG suffers an inability to translate public policy for the private sector into concrete and 
consistent private sector development (PSD) reform action. As noted in the Government’s 
MTDS, difficult country conditions prevail, including corruption, chronic political instability, weak 
management capacity in the Government, an internal system of patronage, social conflicts and 
poor security, and small and isolated markets.7 Government action can alleviate impediments to 
economic growth by providing the public goods and enabling environment necessary to promote 
private sector development. 
 
6.  The PSA concludes that the private sector is constrained by inefficient financial markets, 
insufficient  physical  infrastructure,  inappropriate  legal  infrastructure  (including  regulation  of 
industries), the state crowding out private business in certain sectors, insecurity of land tenure, 
and crime. Although the country is rich in natural resources, its economic development is 
hindered  by  very  low  population densities,  rugged  terrain,  complex  customary  land  tenure 
systems, and poor human resource development. The PSD reform agenda is large and includes 
intractable  issues  caused  in  part  by  vested  political  and  business  interests  and  a  lack  of 
knowledge of PSD good practice among stakeholders. 
 
7.  PSA  recommendations  include  the  need  for  broad  policy  action  in  strengthening 
economic policies, lowering business costs, integrating local markets, developing skills and 
technology, and prioritizing rural development. It recommends that ADB focus on the financial 
sector,  state-owned  enterprise  (SOE)  reform,  and  the  formation  of  appropriate  regulatory 
environments to lower the cost of doing business, reduce the drain on the treasury and pressure 
on public management expertise, and alleviate the crowding out of the private sector. The PSA 
is a good platform for policy dialogue with decision makers and civil society, leading to reform 
roadmaps that select, prioritize, and implement reform measures. 
 
8.  Two principal bodies in PNG work on an agenda that covers a wide range of PSD reform 
activities:  
(i)   NWGIBI was established under the Department of the Prime Minister to identify 
and  propose  measures  to  remove  impediments.  It  is  chaired  by  the  chief 
secretary and consists of stakeholder government agencies and representatives 
from private sector organizations. 
(ii)   The PNG Chambers of Commerce and Industry (PNGCCI), including chapters in 
Port  Moresby  and  Lae,  has  as  members  a  wide  range  of  private  sector 
companies. PNGCCI has good leadership, strong buy-in to its PSD agenda, as 
well as a broad constituency that supports its agenda. However, it lacks the 
resources,  technical  capacity,  and  focus  to  follow  through  on  the  issues  it 
addresses. Technical assistance is needed that would help both NWGIBI and 
PNGCCI promote the PSD agenda. 
 
9.  A lesson learned from ADB’s past support to PNG is that PSD-related projects should  
not  be managed  by  the  public sector.  PSD related  projects have  not  been  managed by the

government and institutions, coupled with high levels of poverty.

public  sector  in  a  transparent  manner  or  in  line  with  project  agreements.8  An  innovative 
approach to project management is thus required, including an institutional set-up that puts the 
civil service at arms-length from day-to-day project implementation. In addition, private sector 
trade organizations have insufficient resources and capacity to follow through on PSD policy 
dialogue with the Government. Current efforts are mainly devoted to putting out fires as they 
flare up. An institutionalized capacity in PNGCCI for promoting good practice regarding PSD 
policy is required.  
 
10.  Support for the creation of an enabling business environment in PNG is fully consistent 
with (i) Government strategies and policies; (ii) ADB’s private sector development strategy;9 (iii) 
ADB’s Pacific Strategy 2005-2009, in which private sector development is a key pillar; and (iv) 
ADB’s CSPU for PNG. Support provided through TA will complement ADB’s ongoing and 
planned PSD-related activities10 and ensure linkages with the activities of other donors. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The proposed TA would contribute to increased private sector activity through a better 
investment climate and increased awareness and knowledge about the enabling environment 
for the private sector. It will achieve this through policy dialogue and reform measures to create 
a demand-driven enabling environment and increase stakeholders’ awareness and knowledge 
of good practice in PSD. Reform activities will benefit both the poor and the formal commercial 
sector by improving (i) the legal and regulatory business environment; (ii) financial services; and 
(iii) the regulation, ownership, accountability, and performance of SOEs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  TA will attain its objectives through both policy dialogue and selected reform action plans 
that can realistically be implemented within the TA period and provide a demonstration effect 
that  will  contribute  to  momentum  for  PSD  reform.  TA  will  reach  beyond  the  Government 
bureaucracy and build buy-in and ownership with politicians, the private sector, and civil society 
through the NWGIBI. Demand for reform and the quality of dialogue between the private sector 
and the Government will be strengthened with the strategically well-positioned PNGCCI as the 
Executing  Agency.  Given  the  difficult  country  conditions,  TA  will  be  opportunistic  in  its 
identification of PSD reform activities through cultivating local ownership and support. As such, 
TA will be flexible in adapting to difficult and changing circumstances, accommodating changes 
and capitalizing on opportunities as they arise. 
 
13.  To attain the TA objectives, the following main activities will be undertaken:  
(i)  Work  with  nongovernment  organizations,  civil  society,  NWGIBI,  and  other 
stakeholders to support the Government’s MTDS.

(ii)  Build support for, prioritize, plan, and implement key activities to support PSD in 
each  PSD  focus  area:  (a)  the  legal  and  business  environment;  (b)  financial 
services; and (c) the role of SOEs and the regulation of key sectors such as 
power, water, telecommunications, shipping and transport, and finance. 
(iii)  Conduct dialogue to disseminate the PSA, raise awareness, and address policy 
issues  through  workshops,  consultations,  and  one-on-one  meetings  with 
Government  officials,  political  leaders,  participants  in  the  private  sector, 
consumers, and others. Use media coverage, seminars, presentations, and issue 
papers to cultivate demand and interest. 
(iv)  Through  training  and  capacity  building,  build  the  local  capacity  to  take  lead 
positions  in  good  practice  regarding  PSD  and  support  coordination  among 
private sector interests.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The  total  cost  of  TA  is  estimated  at  $1.25  million  equivalent,  comprising  $805,000 
foreign exchange costs and $445,000 in local currency costs. ADB will provide $1.0 million grant 
from the Japan Special Fund funded by the Government of Japan. PNGCCI will provide the 
remaining $250,000 in kind by covering office accommodation and support services. Detailed 
cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  PNGCCI will be the Executing Agency and provide office space for TA. The selection of 
PNGCCI is based on an assessment of its strategic position and ownership of the development 
agenda. This partnership will help empower the private sector and instill best practice in private 
sector development. It will ensure intimate knowledge of impediments and constraints faced by 
the private sector at large, as well as a suitable vehicle and entry point for dialogue with the 
Government. Stakeholder government agencies include the Department of National Planning 
and  Rural  Development,  Department  of  Treasury,  NWGIBI,  and  Investment  Promotion 
Authority. Updating and disseminating the PSA is envisaged taking place under the ongoing TA 
6202-REG11 and contributing to this TA. 
 
16.  TA will require about 24 person-months of services from international consultants with 
private  sector  development  expertise  in  areas  including  (but  not  limited  to)  the  legal  and 
regulatory  business  environment;  financial  services;  and  SOE  regulation,  ownership, 
accountability, and performance. A consultant firm will be engaged following the quality-and 
cost-based selection method in accordance with the Guidelines of the Use of Consultants and 
other arrangements satisfactory to ADB. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
17.  TA will begin in February 2006 and be implemented over 24 months until February 2008. 
Support will be provided on an intermittent basis, the duration and frequency of which will be 
based on identified needs and agreed with the consultant firm. Reporting will be on at least once 
a  quarter.  The  consultants  will  report  to  the  ADB  private  sector  development  specialist. 
Comprehensive policy dialogue with Government officials, private sector stakeholders, and the 
general public will be required. Public dissemination of TA outputs will be sought to the extent 
possible.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Papua New Guinea, for the Policies for Private Sector Development, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultants will ensure that all work and outputs under technical assistance (TA) fully 
comply with all relevant Asian Development Bank (ADB) policies and guidelines. One consultant 
will be sought in each of the following broad areas of expertise: (i)  the legal and regulatory 
business  environment  (team  leader);  (ii)  financial  services;  and  (iii)  state-owned  enterprise 
(SOE) regulation, ownership, accountability, and performance. The terms of reference (TOR) 
will need to be adapted and detailed to address evolving contexts and needs. In addition to TOR 
specific to each respective consultant, the team will coordinate closely with the Papua New 
Guinea Chamber of Commerce and Industry (PNGCCI) in the following areas: 
(i)  Support the Government’s Medium-Term Development Strategy. 
(ii)  Work  with  nongovernment  organizations,  civil  society,  the  National  Working 
Group  on  Impediments  to  Business  and  Investment  (NWGIBI),  and  other 
stakeholders. Coordinate responses with other donors.   
(iii)  Build support for, prioritize, plan, and implement key activities to support private 
sector development (PSD) issues in each PSD focus area: (a) the legal and 
business environment; (b) financial services; (c) the role of SOEs and regulation 
of  key  sectors  such  as  power,  water,  telecommunications,  shipping  and 
transport, and finance. 
(iv)  Conduct dialogue to disseminate the PSA, raise awareness, and address policy 
issues  through  workshops,  consultations,  and  one-on-one  meetings  with 
government  officials,  political  leaders,  participants  in  the  private  sector, 
consumers, and others. Use media coverage, seminars, presentations, and issue 
papers to cultivate demand and interest. 
(v)  Build local capacity for dialogue and follow through on PSD issues and support 
coordination among private sector interests.  
(vi)  Through training and capacity building, empower PNGCCI personnel to take lead 
positions in good practice regarding PSD and its implementation. 
 
A.  Experts Required 
 
1.  Private Sector Development Expert, Legal and Regulatory Business 
Environment, Team Leader (international, 8 intermittent person-months) 
 
2.  The expert will have broad insight on PSD issues and international good practice. The 
expert  will  have  at  minimum  a  master’s  degree,  preferably  in  law.  Additional  academic 
qualifications in economics, business administration, or a similar field will be an advantage. The 
successful candidate will have experience in driving policy reform, including (i) demonstrated 
excellent interpersonal and communication skills, (ii) strong political acumen, (iii) experience in 
conducting policy dialogue with decision makers at the highest levels of government and the 
private sector, and (iv) a proven track record in managing reform, preferably in Pacific countries. 
 
3.  Tasks. Work with nongovernment organizations, NWGIBI and other stakeholders to 
build  support,  and  identify  champions  and  opportunities,  for  strengthening  the  legal  and 
regulatory  business  environment.  The  reform  roadmap  must  be  finalized  and  agreed  by 
NWGIBI and other key stakeholders within 6 months of deployment, with implementation of the 
roadmap taking place during the remainder of TA. Activities will include the following: 
(i)  Consult with coordinating and line departments and other stakeholders on the 
larger PSD reform agenda and identify priority issues. Design and implement an

during the remainder of TA. Activities will include the following: 
(i)  Promote financial intermediation by assessing the potential of one or more of the 
following:  (a)  establishing  credit  bureaus;  (b)  instituting  secured  transactions

Appendix 3  11 
reform building on the ADB-supported regional diagnostic studies for collateral 
reform; (c) financial sector regulatory reform; (d) rural savings, credit, pension 
and insurance products; (e) leasing and other financial products; and (vi) capital 
market reforms.   
(ii)  Review  and  reform  the  enabling  environment  for  security  interests  in  fixed 
property. 
(iii)  Review past and existing microfinance initiatives together with the Institute for 
Banking and Business Management and develop TOR for future support. 
(iv)  Provide support to the nucleus agro-enterprise concept and design follow-on TA. 
(v)  By the end of TA, implement, execute, and document at least one action plan for 
reform that will serve as a demonstration project contributing to momentum for 
broader PSD reform. 
(vi)  Coordinate with other donors, as relevant. 
(vii)  Manage the consultative and policy dialogue process. 
(viii)  At the end of the TA, produce a report detailing achievements, lessons learned, 
and possible TOR for follow-on PSD support. 
 
3.         Private Sector Development Expert, SOE Regulation, Ownership, 
Accountability, and Performance (international, 8 intermittent international 
person-months) 
 
6.  The expert will have broad insight on PSD issues and international good practice. The 
expert  will  have  at  minimum  a  master’s  degree,  preferably  in  economics,  business 
administration, public financial management, or a similar field, and experience with transforming 
SOEs. The successful candidate will have experience in driving policy reform, including (i) 
demonstrated excellent interpersonal and communication skills, (ii) strong political acumen, (iii) 
experience  in  conducting  policy  dialogue  with  decision  makers  at  the  highest  levels  of 
Government  and  the  private  sector,  and  (iv)  a  proven  track  record  in  managing  reform, 
preferably in Pacific countries. 
 
7.  Tasks. Build support, and identify champions and opportunities, for improved  SOE 
regulation, ownership, accountability, and performance. The reform roadmap must be finalized 
and  agreed  by  NWGIBI  and  other  key  stakeholders  within  6  months  of  deployment,  with 
implementation of the roadmap taking place during the remainder of TA. Activities will include 
the following: 
(i)  Review government SOE policy and strategy. 
(ii)  Review  impediments  to  SOE  reform  including  the  identification  of  vested 
interests. 
(iii)  Review past PNG attempts to improve SOE performance and translate them into 
lessons learned for the reform roadmap.  
(iv)  Review the regulation of key sectors such as power, water, telecommunications, 
shipping and transport, and finance, as well as the role of SOEs in those sectors. 
(v)  Review regulatory capacity and skills. 
(vi)  Based on reviews and international good practice, develop a roadmap for reform, 
including an outline of economic and financial benefits.  
(vii)  Institute extensive and intensive policy dialogue to build support for the reform 
roadmap. 
(viii)  By the end of TA, implement, execute, and document at least one action plan for 
reform that will serve as a demonstration project contributing to momentum for 
broader PSD reform.

12  Appendix 3 
B.  Timing and Reporting 
 
8.  TA will begin in February 2006 and be implemented over 24 months until February 2008. 
Support will be provided on an intermittent basis, the duration and frequency of which will be 
based on identified needs and agreed with the consultant firm. Reporting requirements will 
include  (i) an  inception  report  within  2  months  of  deployment  highlighting  diagnostics  and 
proposing areas of focus, (ii) a quarterly report to PNGCCI and ADB with an updated activities 
plan and Gantt chart, (iii) within 6 months of deployment, the reform roadmap(s) finalized and 
agreed by NWGIBI and other key stakeholders, and (iv) at the end of TA, a report detailing 
achievements, lessons learned, and possible TOR for follow-on PSD support. The consultants 
will report to the ADB private sector development specialist. Comprehensive policy dialogue 
with Government officials, private sector stakeholders, and the general public will be required. 
Public dissemination of TA outputs will be sought to the extent possible.
